summary.seg: This manuscript begins and ends with four parchment leaves (ff. 1r-4v and 161r-164v: Part 1) that have been taken from a late 13th- or early 14th-century legal manuscript and recycled as flyleaves for this 15th-century medical manuscript. While M.R. James dated the leaves to the 14th century, the dates of the law cases and features of the script leave open the possibility of an earlier composition around c. 1300.

The core of the manuscript (ff. 5r-160v) consists of paper leaves with watermarks that are difficult to identify due to their poor visibility. Throughout, there are medical works and medical recipes in Latin and Middle English that were copied by various 15th-century hands, possibly with some marginal additions made in the early 16th century. Although the core of the manuscript may originate from a single milieu or location, it is possible to identify at least three parts that may have been produced separately from one and another: ff. 5r-69v (Part 2); ff. 70r-123v (Part 3); and ff. 124r-160v (Part 4). That these three parts were created independently of one another is suggested by differences in their layouts, scripts, and quire numbers. Nevertheless, they were almost certainly joined together by the end of the 15th century: the same 15th- or 16th-century hands can be identified among the marginal annotations in all three parts.

What is known about the manuscript suggests that its parts were created and owned in the East of England. While Middle English dialectal features point towards Suffolk and Norfolk [see Language(s)], the manuscript's earliest known owners may have been members of the Spelman family of Narborough, Norfolk [see Provenance].

Dr Clarck Drieshen
Project Catalouger in Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries
Cambridge University Library

supportDesc.support: Paper manuscript with four parchment leaves taken from an older manuscript and reused as flyleaves both at the beginning and end.

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos.

f. [74a] is a small piece of paper that has been stitched to f. 74v with a metal pin. In order to produce a functional electronic catalogue record for this item for the Curious Cures project, the the unpaginated strip was assigned the designation f. [74a].

The modern foliation skips number '134'. This is the result of an error and does not signify that there is a missing leaf between f. 133 and f. 135 (such leaves are sometimes counted in historic foliation practices).

collation.formula: 14 | 212 316 48-1 (1st leaf cancelled) 512 614-1 (14th leaf excised, probably blank) 76-1 (5th leaf cancelled) | 88+1 (1 leaf attached to 6 (f. [74a])) 98 10-1112 1214-1+1 (1st leaf missing and replacement leaf added) | 13-1512 | 164 |
collation.note: This collation deviates from that of James (1896) who identified Quire 4 as a booklet of 6 leaves with an added leaf (6).

binding.p: 17th-century [NB: James (1895) dates the leather to the 18th century] brown leather binding with triple-filetted frames over old (? original) wooden boards with beveled edges and an indentation at the centre of the outer edge of the front board for a strap with potentially the remains of a metal pin protruding through the paper pastedown at the centre of the inside of the lower cover; the spine with four raised bands and a brown leather label featuring a gold-stamped title inscription: MISCELL. MEDICA MSS..
Binding height: 230 mm; width: 145 mm; depth: 50 mm.

provenance.p: Anne Spelman (fl. 16th century) Spelman, Anne, fl. 16th century and Thomas Spelman (fl. 16th century) Spelman, Thomas, fl. 16th century: probably owned the manuscript since their names are inscribed on f. 160v: Anne [2x], Anne Spelman [2x], and Thomas Spelman; f. 168v: Exem. [...] Anne Spelman - Thomas Spelman; and f. 169r: Anne Spelman [...]; perhaps the siblings Anne and Thomas whose parents were John Spelman (c. 1475-1546), Esquire of Narborough, Norfolk, and Elizabeth Frowyke (c. 1479-1556), co-heir of Gunnersbury, Middlesex. John Spelman owned a collection of Yearbooks, now London, British Library, Additional MS 37659 (see Connolly (2013), p. 62 fn. 47).

history.acquisition: Acquired by Jesus College library by 1700: the college's armorial bookplate with the text Collegium Jesu Cantabrigiense 1700 printed on a paper pastedown on the inside of the upper cover; it's classmark 'Q. D. 1.' inscribed in pencil aboce the bookplate and in brown ink in the upper margin of f. 1r [Q - Î - 1 changed from N - Î - 1] and printed on three paper labels pasted on the spine. An old shelfmark H. I. and H.1., which were part of an aborted shelf-mark system used between 1700 and 1705 [see Hanna (2020), p. 73], inscribed in dark ink on the bookplate on the inside of the upper cover and in the upper margin of f. 1r. Another old shelfmark N - Î - 1 inscribed in brown ink at the top of ff. 1r [but the N has been crossed out and replaced with a Q], 5r, and 164v.

recordHist.source: This catalogue record draws on M. R. James, Manuscripts in the Library of Jesus College Cambridge (London, 1895) and Angela M. Lucas, Manuscripts in Christ's Church, Emmanuel, Jesus, Selwyn and Sidney Sussex Colleges, Peterhouse and Trinity Hall, Cambridge, The Index of Middle English Prose, Handlist 22 (Cambridge: Brewer, 2016).

availability.p: Visitors to Jesus College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Old Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Jesus College: Old Library.

[â¦] uersus Simonem de Dullingham (f. 3r); Herbertus de Rysele . Robertus de Heyle [â¦] priori de Symplyngham (f. 3v); Radulphus Basset et Johannes le Heyward [â¦] Willelmo de Tyfford persone med. msItem.title: Law cases
msItem.note: Among the cases are the following personal and place names: Johannes de Hilde tulit breue quod vocatur quare impedit versus quandam Margaretam et dicit quod ipsa [probably the 1270s or 1280s, see Brand, The Earliest English Law Reports, IV (2007), pp. 556-558 [edition and translation of ff. 162v-163v], and Seipp no. 1280.011ss, in Legal History: The Year Books. An index and paraphrase of printed year book reports from medieval English legal history, 1268-1535, compiled by David J. Seipp (Boston University School of Law)] f. 161r); [Rob]ertus filius Ricardi de Adeston Ricardus Gerlande Thomas Styre etcaetera (f. 161v); Thomas de Ashamton (f. 162r); Leycestre . Joan de Wauacour porta vn quare inpedit sur Hadwysa de Neuton [dated to 1276, see Brand, The Earliest English Law Reports, I (1996), pp. 44-46 [edition and translation of ff. 161r-161v], and Seipp no. 1276.001ss, in Legal History: The Year Books. An index and paraphrase of printed year book reports from medieval English legal history, 1268-1535, compiled by David J. Seipp (Boston University School of Law)] (f. 162v); mester Roger de Seytoun (f. 162v and f. 163r) Nicholam de Weston (f. 163r) Margareta que sunt vxor Hugonis de Wynestuwe petit uersus Abbatem de oseneye (f. 163v) Ricardum de Bions Emmam vxorem eius Ranulphum fil Ranulphi de Asrope et Willmam vxorem eius Hugonem de Hinton et Matildam vxorem eius (f. 163v).

supportDesc.condition: The leaves are torn, have holes, and feature ink and/or water stains. Folio 1r is especially affected by these types of damage. A strip of parchment was cut from the lower half of f. 2, causing loss of text.

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame only. Single columns. 32-37 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Copied by a single hand in a cursive Anglicana script.

decoDesc.p: This part of the manusript does not contain any significant decorative features.

origin.origDate: Copied in the late 13th or early 14th century.

msItem.title: Three medical recipes
msItem.note: Recipes ffor to make colman, salue, and oleum vulpum.

msItem.title: Line from a liturgical song
msItem.incipit: 5r ffuit homo missus a deo
msItem.note: This line is repeated, sometimes with only the first two words, various times, on the same page. It is also repeated in the lower margins of ff. 5v, 7r, 8r, 9v.

msItem.title: On the medicinal properties of the secretions of animals and plants, extracted from Books 11 ('tractat de accidentibus scilicet de coloribus et saporibus siue liquoribus et odoribus') and 17 ('tractat de herbis et plantis') of Bartholomaeus Anglicus, De proprietatibus rerum
msItem.author: Bartholomaeus Anglicus
msItem.incipit: 5v Castor est bestia mirabilis que cum quadrupedibus vivit et graditur in terris sub aquis autem natat et comaratur cum natalibus sicut pissis
msItem.explicit: 10r alterius tamen est nature quia frigida et sicca in secundo gradu bedellium uero calidum et humidum ut dicitur in plateario
msItem.note: The text includes tracts on castoreum(Castor), honey (Oximel), wax (De cera et uirtutibus eius), butter (De butiro), cheese (Caseus), gum of the balsam tree (Balsamum), aromatic gum (Bedelium), with citations that are attributed to Isidore of Seville (Ysodoris doctor) and Pliny (Plinius doctor).

msItem.title: Latin-English synonyms for wood resin
msItem.incipit: 6r colyphony [crossed out: "polyphony"] id est pykke
msItem.note: Full transcription; added by the same hand that copied the synonyma on ff. 161r, 69r, 159r. This item is not included in Lucas (2016).

msItem.title: Three medical recipes
msItem.note: The recipes are [t]o make a watyr of ix erbes for alle [erased: maner] deseses of soris, ffor senues Ã¾at bene broken a sundyr or outt, and ffor to make a man or a woman to slepe.

msItem.title: Extracts from books 17 ('De herbis et plantis') of Bartholomaeus Anglicus, De proprietatibus rerum
msItem.author: Bartholomaeus Anglicus
msItem.incipit: 10v Crocus de quo dicitur canticorum .iiij. et trenorum vltimo est erba ab vrbe coricio
msItem.explicit: 12v Nam sumus eius menstrua prouocat et educit secundinas expellit renua conpescit capud et sensus confortat tussientes iuuat et fluxum ventris cedat et in multis medicinis adhibetur vtiliter
msItem.note: Includes passages on Crocus, Porrom [sic: "Porrum'], Balsamum, Edera.

msItem.title: Book 7 ('tractat de infirmitatibus et venenis') with extracts from Books 11 ('tractat de accidentibus scilicet de coloribus et saporibus siue liquoribus et odoribus'), 16 ('tractat de lapidibus et metallis') and 17 ('tractat de herbis et plantis') of Bartholomaeus Anglicus, De proprietatibus rerum
msItem.author: Bartholomaeus Anglicus
msItem.rubric: 12v Incipit liber de infirmitatibus et venenis
msItem.incipit: 12v Postquam compleuimus auxiliante deo tractatum de illorum proprietatibus que homini naturam perficiunt
msItem.explicit: 52r succus [...] confert claritati oculorum huc usque plinius
msItem.note: The text on ff. 13r-52r corresponds with De proprietatibus rerum, Book 7, Chapters 1 ('De dolore capitis et eius signis')-69 ('De medico et eius officio'); it is followed by short accounts of plants, stones, and organic substances from Books 16 and 17, including: Lac, lilium, lactuca, pulegium, pix, plantago, petrocilum, palmirus, singnites, quirini, quamdros, gagates, celidonius, vua immatura, vinum, vinum rubrum, vinum conductum, and viola.

msItem.title: Medical note for or by John Pekeryng [Pickeryng]
msItem.incipit: 32r John Pekeryng the lefte legge from the calfe above Ã¾e kne down to the fote
msItem.note: Full transcription; added in the late 15th or early 16th century by a hand that has added various marginal notes in the manuscript's third part (see ff. 79r, 80v, 82r, 89r, 95r, 95v, 117r, 132v).

msItem.title: Two Middle English recipes
msItem.note: The recipes are ffor wormes in the wombe and ffor an heete in the lyuer.

msItem.title: Anonymous treatise on affections of the eye
msItem.rubric: 52r De passionibus ol [sic] oculorum
msItem.incipit: 52v Auctor iste determinans de passionibus oculorum
msItem.explicit: 61r hec colirium quo vtebatur imperator frethericus et hec sufficit

msItem.title: Uroscopic treatise on the twenty colours of urine
msItem.incipit: 61v [A]lle maner men and women Ã¾at willyn knowen a manees or womans state be here watyr comyth cum a see Ã¾is treteys and Èe xul knowen perfytly alle here medicinis aÈeyns Ã¾o infirmitees Qweche medicynes bene apriuyd be ypocras and be galyene be mawre and be alle docturus Ã¾at tretyn of Ã¾e same matyr
msItem.explicit: 64r cold is cawse of wyte colowr drye is cawse of thynne colowr substawns and moystnes is cawse of thyk substawns Euery vryne ath in regiowns Ã¾e lowest

listBibl.bibl: Tavormina (2014), 47 no. 6.2b [Rufus Subrufus with the "Ipocras" prologue]

msItem.title: Medical recipe for swelling in the body or pain in the heart
msItem.note: The recipe is ffor swellyng in the body or peyne in the hert.

msItem.title: Collection of Middle English recipes
msItem.note: Collection of c. 30 recipes in different hands, including recipes for treating dropsey, pestilence, thirst, urinary retention and incontinence, trembling hands, paralysis in the body, calculus (lump in stomach), migraine (diagnosis), morphea, carbuncle, worms, stab wounds, dead flesh, flux, a bad stomach, a ringworm, phthisic and wind.

msItem.title: Extracts of Books 17 ('tractat de herbis et plantis') and 19 ('tractat de accidentibus scilicet de coloribus et saporibus siue liquoribus et odoribus') of Bartholomaeus Anglicus, De proprietatibus rerum
msItem.author: Bartholomaeus Anglicus
msItem.incipit: 68v Resina vt dicit ysodorus . liber xvij est lacrima sudore lignorum exalata
msItem.explicit: 69r ut patet in plateario quere supra de venis terre .li. xvo.
msItem.note: The extracts are on Resina, Therebintus, Galbanum, and Atramentum.

msItem.title: Latin-English Synonyms for plant names
msItem.incipit: 69r Albenkege id est Moreel Ã¾e more Ventemary bery id est morelle Ã¾e lesse - Nota
msItem.note: Full transcription; added by the same hand that copied the synonyma on on ff. 6r, 159r, 161r. Lucas (2016) transcribes this item as part of a subsequent recipe for a mouthwash. Nevertheless, there is no obvious connection between the synonyms and the recipe. The synonyms were also added by a different hand; the same hand that added the synonyma to margins elsewhere in the manuscript.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for a mouthwash
msItem.note: Added to the bottom of the folio with plawnteyn and vynegyr.

msItem.title: Two recipes to make soap
msItem.note: The recipes are [i]ff Ã¾ow wylt make blac sope and yf Ã¾ow wylt make wyte sope.

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in quarto. Folios 5-69: watermarks are not clearly visible but perhaps include a ? hand in the centre of the inner margin of the page.

signatures.p: Leaf signatures consisting of combinations of letters from the Roman alphabet with Roman numbers visible in the lower right-hand corners of the rectos of the first halves of quires 3 (b), 5 (d), and 6 (c). Quire 7 only contains Roman numerals on its 2nd and 3rd leaves: ij-iij. In quire 3, the leaf signature b ij is followed by 2 b ij, possibly correcting an error.

catchwords.seg: One catchword in the lower right-hand corner of the last verso of Quire 4.

collation.note: This collation deviates from that of James (1896) who identified Quire 4 as a booklet of 6 leaves with an added leaf (6).

layout.seg: Ruled in hardpoint, frame only, but also partial ink ruling on ff. 44v-52r. Single columns. 37-38 lines to the page, written below top line.

p.seg: Ruled in ink, frame ruling, with occasional line ruling on ff. 52v-54v, and continuous line ruling on ff. 55r-61r. Single columns. 30-34 lines to the page, written below top line.
Ruled in ink, frame and line ruling. Single columns. 32 lines to the page, written below top line.
Ruled in ink, frame only. Single columns. Variable numbers of lines (c. 32-38) to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: ff. 5v-52r and 68v-69r were copied by a single hand in a script with both anglicana and secretary features.
ff. 51v-61r were copied by a single hand in a textualis script. This hand may be the same hand that copied ff. 70r-109v and 111r-121r in the manuscript's third part.
ff. 52v-64r were copied by a single hand in a script with both anglicana and secretary features.
ff. 65r-67v were copied by a single hand in a cursive anglicana script.
Medical texts and recipes on ff. 5r 64v 67v-68r, 69v were copied by various hands in cursive scripts with both anglicana and secretary features.

decoNote.p: Large (2 lines) plain initials in red ink on ff. 56r, 57v, 58v, 59r, 59v.
A title rubricated in red ink on f. 52v.
On ff. 52v-60r, plain capitals are highlighted with red ink.

additions.p: Marginal notes that highlight particular recipes in various 15th- and 16th-century hands.

In the lower margin of f. 44r is a rubbing of the reverse of a shilling (measuring about 23mm in diameter) from the reign of Charles II (r. 1660-1685), featuring the garter star in centre with crowned cruciform shields of royal arms with interlinked double C cypher in the angles. The coin may have been a so-called touch piece, which may explain why a rubbing of it was added to a medical manuscript.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Jesus College, MS Q.D.1, ff. 70r-123v

msItem.title: Trotula, English translation [Version D]
msItem.textLang: Middle English text with Latin rubrics
msItem.rubric: 70r Assit principuo sancta maria meo
msItem.incipit: 70r Whanne god maker of alle Ã¾ynkes in Ã¾e furst ordinawns and of Ã¾e world departyd naturis of Ã¾ynges to euerry creatur aftyr hys kende he halowed mankend wyth a synguler dignite abouyn al oÃ¾ir to Ã¾e weche above al oÃ¾ir bestes he ordenynyd condicioun resown and undyrstandyng to Ã¾e wurchyp and Ã¾e fredam of Ã¾e same ordynawns
msItem.explicit: 75v lete hem sette Ã¾er fore in watyr Ã¾at malows be sodyn inne and pulyoll and sche schall be delyueryd Ã¾erof in schort tyme wythowten dowt

msItem.title: Medical recipe
msItem.textLang: Latin with a Middle English plant name
msItem.note: The recipe refers to spearwort with its name in the vernacular: sperewort.

msItem.title: Circa Instans, English translation of the Liber de simplici medicina
msItem.author: Matthaeus Platearius
msItem.textLang: Middle English with Norfolk and Suffolk dialectal features and Latin
msItem.incipit: 75v Aloe is hote and dreye in Ã¾e secunde degre and it is made of Ã¾e juse of an erbe Ã¾at is callyd aloe and Ã¾at erbe is fowd [sic] in jude in perse in grece and in apuleye also
msItem.explicit: 121r Zucarium Sugyr is temperat hote and moyst and is vertu is to moste and to norysche and to lose and if he is medyllyd wyth cold Ã¾yngys to a kele in surryppis to ij li of sukyr Ã¾er schal be putt j li of watyr and Ã¾owe Ã¾er be more it is non harm but for Ã¾e enduryng and here ende Ã¾anke be god
msItem.note: Folio 110 is an added leaf with entries on plants copied by a different 15th-century hand; see MacKinney (1936), p. 412 fn. 46.

msItem.title: Notes on herbs and plants
msItem.note: Refers to agrimony, acacia and buglossa.

msItem.title: Four medical recipes
msItem.note: The recipes are for a colde rewme and oÃ¾ir sykenes of Ã¾e hede and for epilency, to dissolue and to consume and to oppyn and to confortyn senuy membrys ffor epilensy and oÃ¾ir cold sykenes of Ã¾e hede, ffor to make juris lycoris, and for Ã¾e axseyx.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recieps
msItem.textLang: Latin but with two Middle English recipes
msItem.note: The headings of the Middle English recipes on f. 123r are for wynd in Ã¾e guttis and for Ã¾e flyx; not recorded in Lucas (2016).
On f. 123v are to short texts on three days of the year on which bloodletting and the beginning of disease will certainly be followed by death.

watermark.seg: Paper, folded in quarto watermarks are poorly visible but perhaps including a ? bull's head in the centre of the inner margin of the page.

list.item: Quire 1214-1+1 (ff. 110r-123v: 1st leaf missing and replacement leaf added)

signatures.p: Leaf signatures consisting of combinations of letters from the Roman alphabet with Roman numbers visible in the lower right-hand corners of the rectos of the first halves of quires 8 (a), 9 (a), 10 (c), 11 (d), and 12 (e). The leaf signatures in Quire 9 are unusual: a v, a vj, a iij, a iiij.

collation.catchwords: Catchwords in the lower right-hand corners of the last versos of all quires.

layout.p:
70r-109v and 111r-123v
170-190 110-115
Ruled in hardpoint on ff. 70r-71v and in ink on ff. 72r-123v, frame and line ruling. Single columns. 34-37 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: ff. 70r-109v and 111r-121r are written by a single hand in a textualis script. This hand may be the same hand that copied ff. 51v-61r in the manuscript's second part.
ff. 110r-110v are written by a single hand in a script with both anglicana and secretary features.
ff. 121r-121v and 122r-123v are written by a few hands working in scripts with both anglicana and secretary features.
ff. features recipes written by a single hand in a textualis script. This hand may be the same hand that copied ff. 124r-158r in the manuscript's fourth part.

decoNote.p: Large (2 lines) plain initials in red ink throughout.
Titles rubricated in red ink on f. 121v and f. 123r.
Plain capitals are highlighted with red ink throughout.

additions.p: Marginal notes that highlight particular recipes in various 15th- and 16th-century hands. One is a late 15th- or early 16th-century hand that has added "Notas" in light-brown ink on ff. 79r (Nota for makyng of many thyng profytable), 80v (Nota for the Stomake), 82r (Nota for a frenesy), 89r (Nota for Chylde to conseyve), 95r (Nota for the stone stranguria and gowtes), 95v (Nota for Schabbe) 117r (Nota for Ã¾e louer and for the splene, 132v (Nota for rednes in the face). The same hand has added a medical note on a certain John Pekeryng in the manuscript's second part (f. 32r) and "Notas" to the manuscript's fourth part (f. 132v).
A parchment tab on ff. 92r-92v is inscribed with titles for the recipes found on these pages: for clenyng of lyppys and splene.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Jesus College, MS Q.D.1, ff. 124r-160v

msItem.title: Treatise of the making of oils
msItem.rubric: 124r Here begynnyth Ã¾e makyng of oyles for diuerse infirmitees and furst we schalle declare Ã¾e makyng of oyl of laurus and aftyrward procede of oyÃ¾ir
msItem.incipit: 124r Take Ã¾e bayes of Ã¾e laurell or of Ã¾e leuys grene and stampe hem smale and take an erthen pott wyth a lede corde\g/ Ã¾er to and put Ã¾er ynne a potell oyle or a galown aftyr Ã¾in pott may suffice
msItem.explicit: 126v To make oyle of al mawntys or of oÃ¾yr kyrnellys: Take almawdes and blawnche hem Ã¾anne putt hem in a poot an set it a noÃ¾ir seÃ¾inge pott and Ã¾e breey of Ã¾at seeÃ¾inge potte schalle ryse an entre into Ã¾e kernell and Ã¾at wole be godde oyl wan it is wrungune Ã¾orough a clene cloth

msItem.title: The Letter of Ipocras
msItem.rubric: 126v Thys book ypcras sent vnto kynge sasar Ã¾at he desyryd of hym and now I haue made it I send it to yow and wete Èe wele it is gode tresore kepe it welle as yowre owne lyff for I haue made to helpe and hele of yowre body
msItem.incipit: 126v Euery mani [sic: or "mam"] beste and fowle hayth .iiij. humerus weche bene humerus of mannes body Ã¾at is to seye . oon is hote . a noÃ¾ir is colde . Ã¾e Ã¾rid moyst. Ã¾e iiij. drye.
msItem.explicit: 128r and vse hem be Ã¾e morn and at evyn and Ã¾eyes Ã¾inges schulle put awey Ã¾e superfluite of flewme and kepe Ã¾e body in gode temperawnce and in helthe

msItem.title: Treatise on the four regions on the human body where afflications occur
msItem.textLang: Middle English text with Latin heading
msItem.rubric: 128r De quatuor infirmitatibus corporum vbi insurgunt . These bene Ã¾e .iiij. partes Ã¾er Ã¾e sykenes of Ã¾e body begynnen
msItem.incipit: 128r Ã¾at is to sey in Ã¾e hede in Ã¾e breste in Ã¾e wombe and in Ã¾e bladder
msItem.explicit: 129r but he vse Ã¾is [crossed out: "is"] medycen he schalle haue Ã¾e dropsye or Ã¾e lyuere chafed or Ã¾e intrayles stoppyd or ellys Ã¾e stone

msItem.title: Tract on the nine pulses
msItem.rubric: 129r Intra Taury pulsus primus Spira primus compeccionis Colericis significat Tavrus
msItem.incipit: 129r For to knowe Ã¾e dissese of a coleryk man Ã¾at is for to seye a brown man take Take \hese/ pulse in Ã¾in hande and if it meve fast above betwene Ã¾e fel and Ã¾e flesh Ã¾at is smalle be Ã¾e spase of iij vnches to Ã¾e pameward Ã¾anne lyth Ã¾e maledye above Ã¾e mydreff
msItem.explicit: 131r And yf he slepe not and hese botche wex rownd it is toekene of lyff . so Ã¾at Ã¾e kende swellyth Ã¾at is to seye Ã¾e hote agew smytte not in to Ã¾e hede . he is curable ynow ageynne Ã¾e hote sykenes he mote haue cold medicynes

msItem.title: Tract on the nine sage leaves
msItem.rubric: 131r Ã¾e .ix. sawge leuys
msItem.incipit: 131r For to knowe be Ã¾e vij speryis a forseyd wanne Ã¾e levys bene leyd in Ã¾e myddys of Ã¾e hand and holden Ã¾er inne .ij. owres or .iij. tyl Ã¾ey haue take odowr of Ã¾e palme of Ã¾e hand kende swete Ã¾an it is token of lyff and yf Ã¾e swetynge ouyr Ã¾e odowr of Ã¾e sawge Ã¾an is Ã¾e stomak and Ã¾e herte stoppyd ful of glett and englewmed and Ã¾at is a takynyng of deeth
msItem.note: Full transcription. Lucas (2016) considers this tract as part of the preceding tract on the nine pulses.

msItem.title: Treatise on bloodletting
msItem.rubric: 131r To wete an to knowe Ã¾e veynes off blode letynge
msItem.incipit: 131v The veyne in Ã¾e forhede Ã¾e myddyll veyne Ã¾at is gode to blede on . ffor Ã¾e hed ache and for Ã¾e myggryne Ã¾at euyll taketh Ã¾e halff heed and and [sic] maketh Ã¾e hede to ake
msItem.explicit: 133v Tho lete blood on veynes oon Ã¾e feet lete be sett in watyr

listBibl.bibl: Lucas (2016), p. 40 [other copies; transcribes the final rubric as Explicit agnicio sanguinis ffaciendi]

msItem.title: Tract on the four bodily complexions or constitutions
msItem.rubric: 133v De iiij compleccionibus quomodo apparent in corporibus humanis
msItem.incipit: 133v The coleryk man hayth a brown face and somdelle blak and brown or blak herre and brown yeen
msItem.explicit: 135r saue hisse face is sumdele brown Ã¾erwyth a malyncolyk man medyllyd with flewme is a pale man and hys but schort lyvyd

msItem.title: Tract on the number of bones and veins in the human body
msItem.textLang: Middle English with a Latin heading
msItem.rubric: 135r [T]her ben in a mannys body .ij. C. bonys and xvij. And also Ã¾er bene in a mannys body .m.C. veynys. and .lxv. Also Ã¾er ben in a mannes hede Ã¾at hath parfyte age .xxx.ij teth . Vndyrstandyng is in Ã¾e forhede . Mende in ve brayn . Wrathe in in [sic] Ã¾e galle Auarice in Ã¾e stomak Ã¾e galle auarice in Ã¾e stomak . loue in Ã¾e hert . Breeth and blood. troste and feyth in Ã¾e lungys . Joye in Ã¾e splene . jowght in Ã¾e body . hope in Ã¾e sowle Mynde in Ã¾e spryt and feyth
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: The medical recipes are for cancer, colic, griping pain, aching pain, swelling, wounds, a dead or dry limb, easy purgation, cleansing the breast and Ã¾e pypes, and ffor a styche in Ã¾e breste or in Ã¾e stomak.

msItem.title: Tractatus de morbo epidemiae (English translation)
msItem.author: John of Burgundy
msItem.rubric: 137r Here begynyth a nobil tretyse made of a Physyan John of burdews for medysyn ageyn Ã¾e pestylens euylle
msItem.incipit: 137r And it is departyd in to .iiij. partyes The oo partey tellyth howe a man schale kepe hym in tyme of pestilence Ã¾at he falle not in to Ã¾at syekenes The secunde tellyth how Ã¾e sykenesse comyth . The trydde tellyth medycen a geyn Ã¾e sykenes The fowrth how he schal be keppe Ã¾er inne Thys clerke seyth in Ã¾e fyrst capityl Ã¾at for defawte of gode rewel ad dietyng in mete and drynk men fallyn ofte in to sykenes
msItem.explicit: 138v-139r and wo so is Ã¾er inne blede be tyme as Ã¾at oÃ¾ir chappyttyl telleth And rewylle hym aftyr Ã¾e .iij. and thorowe Ã¾e grace of god he schalle schappe Ã¾ys sykenes and be dilyueryd from hym
msItem.finalRubric: 139r Explicit tractatus johannes de burdigalia edititus contra morbum pestilencie qui est morbus epidimialis anno domini millesimo trecentesimo nonagesimo

msItem.title: Instructions for treating the plague with glosses of herbs
msItem.textLang: Latin instructions with glosses in English
msItem.incipit: 139r Unum remedium reseruatiuum inter alia insererem [sic] videlicet quod fugiendum esset a loco vbi regnat mortalitas
msItem.explicit: 139r rose herbe johannis amaruste anglice maythe endyiue agrestis anglice sawthistill acedule anglice sorrell
msItem.note: According to Lucas (2016), p. 129 the instructions are appended to John of Burgundys' plague treatise.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.textLang: Middle English some with Latin headings
msItem.note: The recipes are on de virtutibus elepanpane, for eyes, an anaesthetic, enlarged spleen, breaking a carbuncle, swollen veins, making a poultice, treating the anus, migraine, ointments and unguents for gout, bruises and wounds, intestinal disorders, hearing, scaly skin on the head, recipes for cramp, poor appetite, the kidneys, poor eyesight, pain on the boyd, to encourage menstruation, lessen menstrual flow, scabby skin, and swollen stomach.

msItem.title: Tract on the qualities of the Planets
msItem.textLang: Middle English with a Latin heading
msItem.rubric: 144v De quatuor qualitatibus quomodo diuidentur per influenciam planetarum
msItem.incipit: 144v Saturnus is cold and drye and wo so is born vndyr Ã¾is planite he schal be halff folysch and slowgh and screwednesse doyyng malencolyows in hert and euyl willyng havyng scharp herys and Ã¾inne berd stinkkyng cloÃ¾es and vnclene and mowth blak And he is of hygh desyre in hese \and/ colowr is blaak
msItem.explicit: 145r luna: The mone is cold and moyst and Ã¾ey Ã¾at bene born vndyr here Ã¾ey be somwat medyllyd with Ã¾e oÃ¾ir and Ã¾ey bene vnstabyl messengeris and Ã¾ey bene comonly remaynge abowte and of non abydynge here face is rownd of evyn stature and Ã¾at oon yee of hem is more Ã¾an Ã¾e toÃ¾ir and seelde it is senn Ã¾at oon of hem is wythowtyn wemme

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: The collection includes recipes for the stomach, congestion of Ã¾e pypes, jaundice, diagnosing and treating a morbid swelling, dropsey, headache, legs, palsey, reviving a patient; a section on the virtues of wormwood for sleep, against moths in clothes, swelling under the tongue, tingling in the ears, congestion of the stomach, and sea-sickness; sections on the virtues of plants excerpted from Floridus Macer, Viribus Herbarum (ff. 146v-148v); recipes for the stomach, passing water, against poisonous beasts, cough, a blow to the eyes, sore ears, stone in the bladder; sections onf the uses of camomille, pulyol, and fennel; and a recipe for staunching blood.

msItem.title: Tract on ointments
msItem.rubric: 151r [H]ere begynnyth Ã¾e makyng of nitretys and onimentys for alle maner wondes and sorys
msItem.incipit: 151r A good intret for wondes: Take bugyl . sanycle and consownd Ã¾e lesse Ã¾at is dayse Egrymony . Pimpernol pyclyl plawnteyn Smallache . Cerfoyle and .iij. leuyd gresse Ã¾e croppe of Ã¾e brymbylle Confery . betany lamcelett pervinccyll Avence strawbery wyse Smerwort Osmund and leec
msItem.explicit: 151r Ã¾ys onyment schalle be drunke wyth weyn or wyth ale Ã¾is oniment is gode ffor Ã¾e kanker and for Ã¾e feloun and for alle maner woundes be Ã¾ey neuer so smale no so deep but Ã¾at it wole hele wele and fayre

msItem.title: Tract on medicines used in surgery
msItem.rubric: 151r Hijs medicinis vtimur in cyrurgia pluribus modis et causibus earum
msItem.incipit: 151r Alie sunt debiles alie fortes Alie sunt forciores et alie iterum forciores
msItem.explicit: 151v et fiat vnguentum
msItem.note: The opening also occurs in Guy de Chauliac's Chirurgia magna.

msItem.title: A medical ointment called Mundificatum de resina
msItem.rubric: 151v Vnguentum bonum ad mundicandum neruos et maturandum et saniem attrahendere et dicitur mundificatum de resina

msItem.title: Tract on the treatment of wounds and abcesses
msItem.incipit: 151v-152r Quando cum uulnere fuerit apostema uel mala discrassia non potest curari nec debet nisi sedatur apostema uel mala discrassia congatur et in alio loco dicum est Multum est egris vtile medicum quidem honorabile si membra poterit ab apostemate uulnerata mala que decrassia deffendere nam aliter wulnera non curantur nisi prius ad naturam debitam reducantur
msItem.explicit: 152r et semper agitando cum spatula et de hoc descendatur supra peciam panni et ponatur supra appostema [crossed out: "panni"] donec fuerit maturatum . maturato . nec apostemate fac si potes materiam ad wulnus derivare

msItem.title: Tract on the treatment of flesh wounds
msItem.rubric: 152r De uulneribus que sunt in carne tractare uolentes incipimus a simplicis dicentes
msItem.incipit: 152r quod si uulnus factum fiunt in corpore cum telo uel cultello
msItem.explicit: 154r quod oleum factum fuit de oliuis in maturis scilicet uermium terrestriu[m] conglutmositas [sic] remouet illud membrum dampnum

msItem.title: Medical recipe for wounded nerves
msItem.rubric: 154r Medicina mundificatius nervorum vulneratorum

msItem.title: Tract on the treatment of wounds that result from broken or dislocated bones
msItem.rubric: 154r De uulneribus factis cum fractura ossis et dislocacione
msItem.incipit: 154r Quando uulnera sunt adeo profunda nec solum caro uulneratus set os carni tunc considerandum est vtrum sit totaliter inscisum sicut alij insciditur
msItem.explicit: 155r et farma ordei ad mundificacionem uulneris et intus fila panni albi uetusti usque ad plenam mundifcacionem

msItem.title: Tract on the treatment of wounds that result from contusions
msItem.rubric: 155r De uulneribus que fiunt ex concussione
msItem.incipit: 155r Vulnera fieri dicimus ex concussione que fiunt casu obmateracionem [?] percussione non acute
msItem.explicit: 155v dicta cura in uulneribus neruorum reperiturum [?]

msItem.title: Medical tract with medical recipes
msItem.rubric: 155v In principio cuiuscum operis inuocandum est deum summum artificem medium vnde in isto perhenno inuoco ipsum ut sit michi in auxilum egrotantibus remedium cuius nomen in secula sit benedictum Amen
msItem.incipit: 155v [M]edicina pro corpore humano finaliter componuntur set quia corpus humanum sit ex .iiij. elementis contrarijs . ut ex .igne. aere. aqua. et terra. quibus referuntur etates conplecciones vnde corpus humanum dicitur fragile et transmutabile
msItem.explicit: 157v in estate sic proporcionantur

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: The Middle English recipes for treating wind in the ear (tinnitus), horseseed, sinews, kidneys, pain in the back, rigid throat, fever, pestilence, and for removing hair.

msItem.title: Latin-English synonym for a plant name
msItem.incipit: 159r Anetum id est dylle
msItem.note: Full transcription; added by the same hand that copied the synonyma on ff. 6r, 69r, and 161r.

msItem.title: Saying
msItem.incipit: 161v Dum sumus in mundo vivamus corde jocundo
msItem.note: Full transcription. Copied (with minor variations) four or five times to the page.

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in quarto. Folios 124r-160v: watermarks are not clearly visible but perhaps include a ?circle in the centre of the inner margin of the page.

signatures.p: Leaf signatures consisting of combinations of letters from the Roman alphabet with Roman numbers visible in the lower right-hand corners of the rectos of the first halves of quires 13 (a), 14 (b [written in red ink]), and 15 (a).

p.seg: Ruled in hardpoint, frame and line ruling, but occasional ruling in ink (ff. 125r-125v [frame and lines], 135r-135v [frame and lines], 138r-138v [frame], 147r-147v [frame], 153r [lines], 156v [lines]). Single columns. 33-35 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: ff. 124r-158r were perhaps copied by a single hand in textualis script. This hand may be the same hand that copied a group of recipes on ff. 121v-122r in the manuscript's third part.
ff. 158v-160v were copied by multiple hands in a script that combines both anglicana and secretary features.

decoNote.p: Large (1-2 lines) plain initials in red ink throughout.
Titles rubricated in red ink throughout.
Plain capitals are highlighted with red ink throughout.

additions.p: Marginal notes that highlight particular recipes in various 15th- and 16th-century hands. One is a late 15th- or early 16th-century hand that has added "Notas" in light-brown ink (e.g. N[ota] on f. 132v). The same hand has added a medical note to the manuscript's second part on a certain John Pekeryng in the manuscript's second part (f. 32r), and "Notas" to the manuscript's third part (see ff. 79r, 80v, 82r, 89r, 95r, 95v, 117r, 132v).

change.persName: Dr Clarck Drieshen, Project Cataloguer in Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries, Cambridge University Library
